text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to hot thai kitchen 
so a while back I made a recipe that I call

Thai sukiyaki which is a noodle soup that is our 
version of the Japanese sukiyaki so in that video

I mentioned that there are a few other different 
variations and so today I am going to show you the

dry tsuki or what we call Suki hang and that is 
basically the stir-fried version of that dish it's

actually the one that I prefer like when I go to 
a restaurant that sells soupy I always ordered the

dry version so why didn't I show you this first 
I don't know but here we are I'm going to show it

to you right now super easy let's get started I'm 
gonna start first by marinating my chicken so for

the protein you can use whatever protein you want 
chicken pork beef seafood really popular too I'm

just gonna do chicken breasts because I happen 
to have some in the fridge and I need to use it

up so wouldn't when it comes to chicken breasts 
do not cut them too thin this is the mistake a

lot of people make when they stir-fry with chicken 
breast because it dries out really quickly if you

cut them really thin you don't give yourself any 
time before it dries out simple marinade I have

got some soy sauce kind of smell it I prep this 
yesterday and I don't remember what it is waster

sauce just a touch of sesame oil because that 
is the flavor of our sukhiya sauce so we want

to reflect that same flavor in the chicken this is 
not gonna work so let's do tongs today so you want

to do this first so it has some time to just sort 
of sit and hang out and absorb now let's make the

sauce which is the most important part of this 
you cannot have a tsuki without this sauce so

I've made this before in my original Sookie Nam 
version this is the same sauce but we'll do a

quick review okay I've got some garlic cloves here 
which I'm gonna pound into a paste with some Thai

chilies you can make this as spicy or it's not 
spicy as you want you can omit it all together

pound it into a paste you can throw everything 
into a blender if you want I'm gonna throw it

now some sugar the sugar will add some friction 
which will help the garlic grind more finely

and then I'm going to add some toasted white 
sesame seeds crush it gently just to help it

release the aroma you still want to see a hole 
sesame seeds so now this is what you've got next

ingredient is the most important thing so you 
really want to make sure you can find it but

it's not that hard to find just go to a Chinese 
grocery store and you look for red bean curd it

comes in a glass jar and inside you get these 
mushy cubes red cubes like this this is what

gives it's the the key flavor of Sookie and Thai 
this is called the Hui and so I'm just gonna add

these cubes into my mortar here and I'll leave 
the liquid for later so that it doesn't splash

everywhere when I try to smoosh these things down 
which I forgot to do last time and I have learned

now that it is a really sticky paste like that I'm 
gonna add all the liquid ingredients which is the

juice from the bean curd some white vinegar and 
some soy sauce I say that as though it were the

last thing but it is not because you also need 
toasted sesame oil very important so that's it

that's all you need and ideally you want to make 
this ahead of time as much as you can do it day

before but if you can do it like half an hour 
before it gives a garlic and the sesame gives

it time to mingle the flavors to mingle with 
one another I find it tastes better that way

you can make a whole bunch of this and keep it 
in the fridge that'll last you forever oh not

literally forever but a very long time okay so I'm 
gonna go through the other ingredients real quick

the ingredients look exactly the same as the soup 
version if you've made that before because this is

simply just a stir-fried version so I got glass 
noodles which I have soaked in room-temperature

water for about 10 minutes until it's completely 
pliable and I just cut it a few times to shorten

the noodles so that it's easier to eat for 
Sookie we always use glass noodles you can

substitute if you want but it's not gonna be the 
same we never have Sookie with any other noodles

except glass noodle vegetables classically we do 
napa cabbage and this is Morning Glory also known

as water spinach or inside boom if you can't find 
it you can just do any dark green vegetables like

bok choy would be good and then Chinese celery is 
typical but I can't find it so I just use regular

celery and then I just add more leaves it's a 
good way to use celery leaves which most people

don't end up using and then you've got a couple 
of eggs and that is pretty much it so I'm gonna

start out by searing my chicken as usual I wait 
for that to get hot not hot yet that's how you

temperature okay that looks hot yeah that's hot 
okay so the chicken go finish and we're gonna

cook it all the way so that's one side sphere 
then when it's about half way done please flip

it toss it around so I am gonna cook my chicken 
separately because I'm doing chicken breasts and

so I want good control of the doneness when I do a 
chicken thigh I usually just sear the outside and

then throw everything else in our circus chicken 
thigh is a lot more forgiving in terms of doneness

like it's not gonna dry out if you overcook it a 
little bit chicken breast not ask much so I just

cook it all off remove it throw it back in at the 
end okay so that's done I'm gonna turn that off

get the chicken out turn the heat back on you can 
add a little bit more oil and I'm gonna go in the

width actually vegetables cook that down a little 
bit and because the origin story of this dish is

a hot pot it's got a lot more vegetables than it 
does have noodles so don't think of this as like

Oh a sir fried noodle this it's really more of 
like a surprise of all this food noodles in it

okay so get that a little bit wilted I'm gonna 
go in now with my noodles and then the sauce and

now we're just gonna cook all of that until the 
noodles absorb all the sauce if it looks dry but

it's not done yet you can add a little water or a 
chicken stock if you have it glass noodles do not

take very long so don't over don't overwater it 
okay that looks good well let that absorb all the

liquid looking mostly dry I'm going now push it 
to one side you can add a little more oil if you

want for the eggs my eggs go in I'm gonna break 
that throw that on top of the eggs and just let

it sit for a little bit so the eggs cook oh don't 
forget to throw in your chicken too at this point

with all the juices and everything and then you 
mix everything yep that is a lot of chicken and

we're at home so we can spend as much money as 
we want on protein and that is it you guys I'm

gonna kill the heat throw in some cilantro for 
garnish at the end cuz cilantro makes everything

look better you can do green onions if you want 
I'm telling you there is just nothing it's smells

quite like Sookie and I just want to point out 
notice how it looked like we added a ton of

vegetables but they wilt and now it doesn't look 
like all that much that's why we need it to add

that much because both of all of our vegetables 
are ones that shrink always extra cilantro want

because cilantro makes everything look better now 
I like to eat mine just like this however I always

usually serve an exercise of the Suki sauce so 
that if somebody thinks this is a little too mild

they can pour a little extra suki sauce on it to 
like really amp it up in terms of flavor now let's

see you want to get some vegetables some chicken 
the egg is already mixed in there so it's all good

perfect it's such a unique flavor the chicken is 
super tender that's because you take care to cook

it separately remove it you got the noodles it's 
soaked in that sauce flavor and the vegetables are

kind of crunchy so you got lots of flavors going 
on sweet and sour is sort of where this thing is

that but but the funk from the red bean curd is 
so unique and nothing like you've ever had before

you've never had red bean curd it's a it's it's 
a thing to try not that hard to find if you go to

a Chinese grocery store it's a common Chinese 
ingredient so make sure you look for that oh

and what do you serve this with this is one of 
those dishes in Thai cuisine that's a one dish

meal where you would order it and you just have 
this on its own from lunch so it's really popular

with like quick order sort of street vendors 
or like in a food court because makes it cooks

really quickly and you just eat it for lunch 
it's well-balanced of carbs protein vegetable

it is just so good if you've already tried the 
soup version try this one cuz you already got the

sauce if you've never tried the soup version 
try both because they are just different and

delicious in their own way the recipe as always 
will be on hot Thai Kitchen calm when you make

it I definitely want to see a photo on Facebook 
Twitter or Instagram and if you haven't subscribed

to the show make sure you do so you don't miss an 
episode like this and click the bell icon as well

and application echo send me video thank you as 
always for watching and I'll see you next time

he jumps really high catch it he can jump from
